answerText: Hamlet[10] Hamlet mentions "the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune" in his soliloquy that begins by positing this famous question.
heading: Western Invitational Tournament |2013 | Bentley Gioia Hunter Lopez-Lago | 14 | Literature | British | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: This character laments, "How all occasions do inform against me" in his last major speech and earlier claims, "Conscience does make cowards of us all". For 10 points each: [10] Name this character who asserts, "O, that this too too solid flesh would melt" in a speech that includes the famous quote, "Frailty, thy name is woman!"
